After a while, you realized that these checks must be performed sequentially. The application attempts to authenticate a user to the system whenever it receives a request that contains the user's credentials. However, if those credentials aren't correct and authentication fails, there's no reason to proceed with any other checks.

The request travels along the chain until all handlers have had a chance to process it. Here's the best part: a handler can decide not to pass the request further down the chain and effectively stop any further processing.

suggests that GUI objects shouldn't send these requests directly. Instead, you should extract all of the request details, such as the object being called, the name of the method and the list of arguments into a separate

For a product, it's simply the price. For a box, it goes through each item the box contains, asks its price and then returns a total for this box. If one of these items were a smaller box, that box would also start going over its contents and so on, until the prices of all inner components are calculated.

Some of the form elements may interact with others. For instance, selecting the "I have a dog" checkbox may reveal a hidden text field for entering the dog's name. Another button might have to validate values of all fields before submitting.
